ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a considerable amount about our deep history and many of the meta-narratives throughout history. The reading requirement was quite heavy (usually one book per week) but most of the books were quite interesting.

An up-to-date understanding of broad-scale historical trends such as political instability, technological development, globalization, the spread of agriculture, European expansion, etc. Also, the ability to evaluate an authors' argument and evidence, the skill of deriving the important information from a book without reading the entire thing, historiographic/synthetic essay writing.
Trends in global history and historical methods of defining and analyzing these trends

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: While small seminars have their upsides, this course could use with a few more students.

This was a fantastic course, guaranteed to make you think in new ways and reconsider many of the dominant narratives about why the world is the way it is. The sole weakness was that we only had six people, and the ideal size would probably be about ten.
So much reading but very interesting and fun discussions. Professor leaves very detailed feedback on short papers.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. Anyone who is interested in being a thoughtful, engaged citizen of the world ought to take this course, regardless of major.

Yes, if you have interest in thinking about big trends in history, this is a great class. It's challenging because you discuss a different book each week and sometimes write a response paper before the class discussion, but you learn a lot about both world history and how to think about world history.
